oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituary for Horace Nims
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An obituary for Horace Nims, M. D., read before the Onondaga Medical Society by Alfred Mercer, M. D. Dr. Nims graduated from Geneva Medical College in 1837 and opened a practice in Manlius, NY. He became an assistant surgeon in the Army in 1862, but ill health led him to resign, with an honorable discharge, in 1863. He lived in Manlius until his death. Dr. Mercer graduated from Geneva Medical College in 1943 and was a well-known, highly respected physician and medical educator in Syracuse, NY.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Alfred Mercer, M. D.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituary for James Kendall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Kendall graduated from Geneva Medical College in 1844 and practiced medicine in three towns in Central New York: Pulaski, Clay and then Baldwinsville. He was also very active in the Onondaga and Oswego Medical Societies. Dr. Mercer was a junior member of the same class, graduating in 1943, and was a well-known, highly respected physician and medical educator in Syracuse, NY. The obituary also contains a description of the state of medical education in the mid-1800s, as compared to the beginning of the 20th century when the address was delivered.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Alfred Mercer, M. D.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geneva Medical College, from west side of South Main Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Taken from west side of S. Main St. on Seneca Lake, the Medical Institution of Geneva College is the building with the cupola. It housed the medical school from 1841-1872 and is the building from which Elizabeth Blackwell graduated. The building burned in 1877. Caption reads, "Geneva medical college, Geneva NY. View of later building showing street on which it was located."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Middle Building, Geneva Medical College
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first building of Geneva Medical College, the Middle Building stands between Geneva Hall on the right and Trinity Hall on the left. A horse and wagon are visible to the right. Built by A. A. Bird of Ithaca in 1835, it was refurbished in 1846 to house the library, recitation rooms and President's office. A cupola was later moved to the Middle Building from Geneva Hall. The building burned in 1885.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Discusses universal laws of nature defined by physical and mental development the and conditions essential for health. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Address to the Woman's Medical College of the New York Infirmary
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A speech delivered at the opening of the Woman's Medical College in New York, N. Y. Describes the 15-year task of acquiring funding and professional support, as well as the difficulties women faced in medicine at the time. Blackwell also generally describes the plan of instruction, with special attention devoted to hygiene.
